sentence:
…both  sides of the aisle, including one occasion where a GAO letter gave rise  to a joint resolution of disapproval which became law?

Mr. PADILLA. I thank the Presiding Officer.

Mr. PADILLA. Mr. President, I wonder if any other Member of this  Chamber grew up like I did where on a pretty regular basis, we would be  sent home from grade school because…
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Schmitt). The Senator from Minnesota.                                 S.J. Res. 77

The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Sheehy). Under the previous order, the  Senate will resume consideration of S.J. Res. 31.

Under the previous order, all debate time is expired. The clerk will  read…
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Mullin). The Senator from Iowa.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Justice). The Senator from Wisconsin.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Justice). Under the previous order, the  question is, Will the Senate advise and consent to the Kupor  nomination?

The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Wicker). On this vote, the yeas are 51,  the nays are 46.

The motion is agreed to.

The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Cramer). On this vote, the yeas are 63,  the nays are 32.

The motion is agreed to.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Tuberville). The Senator from Florida.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Sheehy). The Senator from Hawaii.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Curtis). The majority leader.                                Cloture Motion
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Justice). The Senator from North Dakota.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Moreno). The Senator from Vermont.
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Hagerty). Under the previous order, the  Committee on Finance is discharged from and the Senate will proceed to  the consideration of S.J. Res. 88, which the clerk…
The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Marshall). The majority leader.

The PRESIDING OFFICER (Mr. Banks). Under the previous order, all  postcloture time is expired.

The question is on agreeing to the motion to proceed.
